eventHeadline: Mexico gains independence from Spain (1821)
Joel Robert Poinsett embarks on a special mission to Mexico, publishing an account of his experiences in 'Notes on Mexico' (1822)
The United States recognizes Mexico as an independent nation (1823)
United States president James Monroe articulates the Monroe Doctrine in his seventh annual message to Congress (1823)
Joel Robert Poinsett is appointed first U.S. minister to Mexico (1824)
Over several years, empresario Stephen F. Austin attracts the first 300 American families into the Coahuilas y Tejas territory (1825)
American empresario Haden Edwards leads Fredonian Rebellion in an attempt to secede from Mexico (1826)
Mexico abolishes slavery (1829)
Mexican-owned Tejas is home to roughly 20,000 Americans (1830)
Mexico prohibits immigration to Tejas from the United States in an effort to stop the influx of English-speaking settlers (1830)
American immigrants and Tejanos lead the Texas Revolution on behalf of the Tejas province of Mexico as part of a larger Mexican Federalist's War (1835)
The Battle of the Alamo (1836)
An independent Republic of Texas is declared during the Texas Convention (1836)
Santa Anna surrenders after defeat in Battle of San Jacinto; Treaties of Valasco unofficially marks Rio Grande as the border between Mexico and the Republic of Texas (1836)
Mexico defends itself successfully from French invasion during the 'Pastry War'; Santa Anna's role helps him regain popularity (1838)
Santa Anna returns to the Mexican presidency, ordering the military to pressure the Mexican-Texas border (1841)
San Antonio is taken and returned several times; a back-and-forth of Mexican militants and Tejanos crossing the border for raids and returning to Mexico continues (1842)
Expansionist Democrat James K. Polk becomes U.S. President (1845)
Mexico refuses to negotiate the acceptance of Texas' annexation into the United States (1845)
Republic of Texas annexed into the United States as the 28th state (1845)
President James K. Polk orders General Zachary Taylor to occupy disputed territory between the Nueces and Rio Grande rivers (1846)
Mexican troops at Matamoros cross the Rio Grande and ambush an American patrol, which President Polk declares an act of war (1846)
Mexican-American War begins (1846)
The United States army marches towards Mexico City from the north while the United States navy takes Veracruz via amphibious assault (1847)
The United States army takes and occupies Mexico City (1847)
The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo is signed, ending the Mexican-American War (1848)
Gadsden Purchase is finalized and signed, forming the current day borders between the United States and Mexico (1854)
Invoking the Monroe Doctrine, the United States provides diplomatic and material support to Mexico during the French Intervention in Mexico (1861-1867)
Mexico encourages repatriation of Mexican-Americans back into its northern territories (1870s-1890s)
Porfirio Díaz seizes power in Mexico with the financial support of U.S. entrepreneurs from South Texas (1876)
The Porfiriato government strengthens U.S. - Mexico economic ties through mining and railroad investments (1884-1990s)
Discontent with the Porfiriato leads to Mexican Revolution, U.S. involvement and interventions strain relations (1910-1917)
'Pact of the Embassy' brokered by US ambassador Henry Lane Wilson to Mexico, leading to Francisco Madero's assassination and Victoriano Huerta's ascension to Mexican presidency (1913)
Woodrow Wilson elected President of the United States and embargoes weapons and supplies to Huerta's Mexican Federalist troops (1913)
President Wilson sends US marines to occupy Mexico's port of Veracruz, heightening tensions between the two countries (1914)
President Wilson orders the Pancho Villa Expedition, which ultimately fails (1916)
President Wilson and Venustiano Carranza agree to a Joint High Commission, leading to the withdrawal of US troops from Mexican territory (1916)
Venustiano Carranza elected president of Mexico (1917)
Zimmermann telegram is intercepted by the British and sent to the United States, swaying public opinion in favor of joining the World War (1917)
Bucareli Agreement of 1923 (1923)
'Good Neighbor Policy' implemented by US President Franklin Delano Roosevelt (1933)
Lázaro Cárdenas expropriates and redistributes more than six million acres of U.S.-owned property in Mexico during his presidency (1934-1940)
Cárdenas nationalizes Mexico's petroleum sector (1938)
Roosevelt pushes US owners of oil companies to end their boycott of Mexican crude oil and accept adequate compensation for repossessed properties (1938)
Mexico stops trading with Germany (1939)
Mexico stops trading with Italy and Japan (1940)
Mexican President Manuel Ávila Camacho severs relations with Japan, Germany, and Italy after the attack on Pearl Harbor (1941)
Mexico declares war on the Axis powers (1942)
Bracero Program starts, allowing Mexican agricultural workers to work temporarily in the US (1942)
Mexican expeditionary fighter squadron “Aztec Eagles” gives aid to US efforts in the Philippines (1945)
250,000 Mexicans and a million Mexican Americans serve in the U.S. armed forces during WW2 (1941-1945)
Some 300,000 U.S. tourists visit Mexico annually (1947-1948)
Mexican leaders praise the Cuban Revolution and refuse to sever diplomatic ties with Castro's government, despite pressure from the US President John F Kennedy (1961)
Bracero program ends (1964)
The U.S. introduces the Immigration and Nationality Act, changing how immigration quotas are managed (1965)
United States backs the Institutional Revolutionary Party during the Tlatelolco Massacre (1968)
US President Richard Nixon launches Operation Intercept, causing US customs officials to begin searching each and every border-crossing vehicle for drugs (1969)
Drug Enforcement Administration is established in the US to coordinate drug enforcement efforts (1973)
Mexican government begins Operation Condor in an effort to eradicate and interdict drugs (1975)
Guadalajara cartel, one of the first major Mexican drug cartels, is formed (1980)
Mexico signs agreement with the International Monetary Fund to reschedule debt payments, opening foreign trade and investment (1982)
US leaders grudgingly accept Mexican support for Nicaragua's Sandinista government and lead efforts to find peaceful resolutions to conflicts in the region (1983)
DEA agent Enrique "Kiki" Camarena is kidnapped, tortured, and murdered by the Guadalajara Cartel, leading to increased U.S.-Mexico cooperation on drug enforcement (1985)
The US begins the certification process, evaluating countries' efforts in combating drug trafficking. Non-cooperative countries risk losing US aid and trade benefits (1989)

Immigration and Reform Control Act allocates new resources to the Border Patrol, sanctions US employers who hire illegal workers, and offers amnesty legalization to long-term undocumented residents and agricultural workers (1986)
North American Free Trade Agreement, or NAFTA, deepens US and Mexican economic ties (1994)
California adopts Proposition 187, denying undocumented residents access to nearly all public services, including schools and hospitals (1994)
Congress passes the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 (1996)
Mexico passes the 1996 Constitutional Amendment on Dual Nationality (1996)
General Jesús Gutiérrez Rebollo, Mexico's top anti-drug official, is arrested for protecting a cartel leader, highlighting corruption issues (1997)
Marking the end of 71 years of Institutional Revolutionary Party rule, Vicente Fox is elected President of Mexico, promising to combat drug cartels (2000)
